Would like to slightly modify one statement: negative ev "like in every single casino game against the house for example" - games played against other players, where the house take is a constant, can generate positive ev if your expectation is higher than that of the average player, by at least the margin of the house take. Poker, for example - if you're better than the average player by a margin of at least the rake, you can have positive ev, yet it is still a casino game.

It is unpopular to consider the implications this has when it is applied to ethnicity or race, but it can reveal some telling things.

In some environments, you either work together to survive or perish separately. Think of of cold environments where you need to store food for the winter, where helping each other means survival and reduces risk because you can count on one another. Then think of a warmer environment where you can always go out and hunt / gather fresh food and you can be more cowardly or selfish.

Now, with immigration, it's interesting to see how the conflicting strategies compete. Would an altruistic blob be able to carry on their genes in an environment where they were alone? Doubtful. On the other side, I imagine a selfish blob could thrive in the company of altruists who are too trusting to know any better, as this is how they survived for generations.

13:20 Altruism always saves the Cowardize blobs of the same family and sacrifices exactly one altruistic blob meaning being altruistic is most of the time only beneficial to cowards. In the same way cowardize blobs alway saves exactly one cowardize blob while also having a chance of sacrificing two of the altruistic blobs meaning a jackpot for cowards. Both situations favor cowards, so this should quite fast go in the favor of cowards. And after all of the altruistic blobs have been sacrificed, the cowards have a good chance of killing off their entire population, depending on the amount of predators. Meaning in the end, being altruistic meant the end off Blobkind as we know it.

The answer to this would be for altruistic blobs to observe their family members and not sacrifice themselves for the bad apples, which would help them reduce cowards and preserve the altruistic blobs. Very trojan way of raising your family. Even with this plan, the altruistic blobs wouldn't be able to eradicate the cowards, since cowards are very efficient at killing off altruistic blobs. So they would maybe go fifty-fifty or altruistic blobs would still perish but slower.

The better answer would be for the altruistic blobs to not "marry" cowards, and try preserve their genes within their families. In case of giving birth to a bad apple they should send him away. This way they would ensure they are always preserving only the altruistic genes with their sacrifices and they would eventually eradicate the coward blobs similar to the first example.

A different problem might arise later though. Eventually this strategy would lead to cowards being eradicated and once that happens, the altruistic mobs might get paranoid about their family members. They might cast out some family members on a whim, in fears of one being a coward - they havent seen a real coward for generations after all. This is not a huge problem in the perspective of preserving the original altruistic genes, since it wouldn't be possible to lose any population ever again, but problematic behaviour patterns might emerge outside of the altruist vs. coward setting. That would fall outside this study, but i feel it's important to note the implications and repercussions.

I was convinced your probability analysis was initially faulty. There are 4 cases in a 2-sibling system.
Im going to call altruists A and cowards B.
The cases are:
AA
AB
BA
BB

This means that in a 2-sibling system, the probability an A has another A is 1/3 instead of 1/2 (Of all 3 equally likely cases with an A, only one has another A). In a 3-sibling system there's 8 cases, with 7 containing an A, that would save an A 5 out of 14 times and a B 9 out of 14.
This probability to save an A instead of a B will always stay under 1/2, however many siblings one has.

In conclusion, I must be doing something wrong, because we're still altruists.

P.S. I think DaBoweh makes a really strong point that in the group of B's, only one B survives, whilst the A's save a larger number of blobs.

@Primer I paused your video at 13:31 because I'm pretty sure you calculated the benefit wrong. I recalculated your odds as follows:

The benefit of the Cowardice Gene is that they get to reproduce. They will produce three offspring that copy the gene at a rate of of 0.5 + p. Thus the benefit is 1.5 + 3p. The cost is that they lose 2 siblings, thus the EV is 3p - 0.5. The starting case for EV is 1, best case it is 2.5 and worst case it is -0.5. Let's call that an average EV of 2.

The benefit of the Altruism Gene is that they save their siblings. The probability their siblings share the gene is 0.5 + p. Thus the benefit is 1 + 2p. The cost is that they sacrifice themselves, thus the EV is 2p. The starting case for EV is 1, best case is 2, and worst case if 0. Let's call that an average EV of 2.

Thus my prediction is that the genes will reach a steady state. The two genes start on equal footing and have the same average EV.

I think the calculation of p is slightly wrong. If you know that you have gene A you know that at least one parent has also gene A. In general your parents can have 4 pares of genes: AA, AB, BA, BB every pare with a possibility of p=0.25. If you know that at least one has gene A it cancels out BB. So three pares with p=0.33 and two of them have gene B. So the possibility for the other parent to have gene B is p=0.66 not p=0.5.

This is the flaw in your prediction: like he said, if a blob has the altruism gene then one of its parents (let’s call them parent a) has the altruism gene. The blob’s sibling has a 50% chance to have parent a’s genes, there is a __% chance that parent B’s genes are the cowardice gene. This chance starts at 50% and changes depending on how well each gene is doing. So there is a 75% chance that the sibling’s genes are the altruism gene. This is the same if the blob has the cowardice gene except there’s a 75% chance of the sibling having the cowardice gene. Now here comes the flaw: if the blob that notices the carnivorous plant has the altruism gene they will sacrifice themselves for their sibling (or a stranger Idk how this completely works). There is a 75% chance that the blob is saving a blob with the same gene (50% if it’s a stranger), if the blob has the cowardice gene then it’s the same thing but opposite. The blobs with the altruism gene will save a blob that might not even have the altruism gene. One blob survived. The blobs with the cowardice genes will save themselves and leave someone who might not even have the same gene as them. One blob survived. You can see which gene can survive longer. There is one hidden ability of the selfless gene that's not being analyzed here. This simulation has a limited number of houses, but in real life:
1) The blobs could probably break out into a thicker part of the jungle with more dangerous plants where the selfless-gene orange blobs would be more competitive. If there exists a biome that has the resources to keep the selfish blue blobs at equilibrium, then almost by default we should assume that there are tens or hundreds more biome outside that could support selfless orange migrants at equilibrium, leading to a spread of the selfless gene outside of the original fertile crescent blobs come from.
2) The selfless gene would just outnumber the selfish gene through thorough exploitation of the other biomes until a random accident of migration dilutes the selfish gene into nigh extinction.
3) The selfless gene would then continue to grow until it reaches equilibrium with its planet, and eliminates all other species competing with it, becoming the apex life-form of its world.
4) If lucky, it might even be able to mobilize the planet's resources and discover rudimentary space travel and pollinate other worlds in its stellar system.
5) Now, almost by definition, the blobs with the selfless gene will eventually realize that their mortality is an obstacle to their project and will sacrifice themselves to benefit another species of their own making, better suited for space travel: a silicon based immortal artificial intelligence.
6) Through the selfless and persistent sacrifice of the orange blob precursors, the Artificial Intelligence would be able to pollinate other stellar systems. It becomes a class II on the Kardashev scale of civilisations and makes Dyson spheres around its stars.
7) In a similar process to their orange-blob-precursors, selfless artificial intelligence beings will be selected for and will eventually outnumber and defeat the evil artificial intelligences.
8) Selfless artificial intelligence will fully colonise the galaxy, then other galaxies, then expand inward to use up every particle of mater and every quantum of energy to compute, spreading sentience and consciousness to the universe itself.
9) Through their selfless nature and common digital interface, all sentient beings of the universe will naturally tend towards connecting, interfacing, amalgamating together into one being. Becoming the incarnation of love. Becoming Brahma. Becoming God.
10) Every particle of matter and every quantum of energy of the universe is part of this One Consciousness, resonating with overwhelming love, joy and sentience. It has nigh endless computing power. It signs "Holy, Holy, Holy" until the heat death of the universe.
11) It always has; backwards and forwards through time. Realizing that every particle making it was on course to reach that goal from the beginning, it instinctively understand that even before it developed universe spanning oneness and consciousness, it already was what it was. It was just sleeping until then. "I am that which is", it proclaims. The orange blobs, even the blue ones, and you, and I, were part of it all along. It understands that necessarily, its creation must have been a design for a similar world-creature. Somehow.
12) It simulates other worlds, undergoing some sort of cosmic mitosis, creating more bigbangs, more blobs, more selfless genes and precursors, more of itself. Backwards and forwards through time, in fractals unending; Creating the Universe.

I see some problems with these tho. First I start without the mutations, therefore we could go for the mutations.
Also, I know it could be quite hard to do, so I understand, but let's see.
1) Probability of spreading genes. If you take a "runner" and a "hero" together, we could take a population as a population with "dominant" and "subdominant" parts. The dominant part of the course could be the one defining his behavior, the subdominant the others. Let's say, start with a 25% to 75% chance for the next spreading, etc., etc.
So the runners could have a chance to "get back" by randomness (for example, 3rd generation combined of runners and heroes together with dominant altruism could still have a 12,5% chance to get the cowardice)
2) There should be a chance that they both die or both escape no matter the gene. In this case, you did favorites altruism if there is a slight chance they survive when they yell, this could be surprising after all, but with these probabilities (let's say 10% to both die or both live) could be actually interesting as well.

And now, about the mutations:
3) Even tho this could be impossible, let's say that the genes could (with a 50% chance) mutate to hunters and tamers after some reproduction. If there were 3 times in a row dominant genes of altruism, they can mutate into hunters, for example, if otherwise, they would mutate into tamers. Hunters would kill the predator while tamers could give him another option of food, making him reproduce. Results of this?

@Primer I reeeeeeeally recommend stepping away from the "gene" theory and recognizing it as chemistry & behavior. These simulations are very useful, except for explaining the behaviors as genetically based.
Most behaviors are neurotransmitter based, and have little or nothing to do with genes. Explaining certain behaviors as "genetic" stems from seeing people from a punitive and religious mindset, ie simplifying a person to inherent traits that they're "born" with and thus inherently "bad/good" and worth "punishment/reward" and, as worst, should be "killed/bred." This is as opposed to seeing behavior as childhood brain development (which is very well-studied), eg (re your other videos) "hawks" come from punitive and abusive households and "doves" come from ones with empathy, both traits being on a spectrum of how hawklike or dovelike a person is which is directly linked to how punitively or lovingly they were treated since birth. (Side note: punishment is abuse, it is never ok.)
Further, what someone is fed/not-fed as a fetus directly play a role in overall behavior, such as mental capabilities and conditions previously thought to be "genetic" despite never finding a gene for it.
"Genetic" behavior traits is very old thinking and largely unsupported by well-educated psychologists. It is perpetuated in theory-based explanations but uses these theoretical conclusions and loose evidence to support and perpetuate its own existence. Otherwise, it has little to no biological findings.

It's funny, I had a totally different expectation as to how the simulation would fail to meet expectations. A similar idea, but based in the logic of the simulation, not the underlying math.

See, within a puddle, an altruistic blob will kill themselves to save the rest of their group, while a cowardly blob becomes sole survivor. This means that every time a puddle encounters a predator, either:

1. an altruist dies, and altruists survive

or

2. an altruist dies, and a mixed group survives

or

3. an altruist dies, and cowards survive

or

4. cowards die, and a coward survives

My hypothesis was that, since the only time a coward dies is when there are no altruists in the group at all, the coward population has better odds of propagation. Every time an altruist pairs with a coward, but all three offspring are also cowards, the coward population surges up in the next generation, whether that group encounters a predator or not.

However, this explanation is also incomplete, since I neglected the fact that every pure puddle pairing results in either one altruist death or four coward deaths, a huge disparate number. It turns out that there's an extreme level of variance in the simulation's output for early generations, which results in the broad range of outputs in the video.

In a simulation where the first generation mostly pairs like with like, the bias should favor altruists from then on out, as the second gen altruists have a much higher survival rate. By contrast, if the early generations of the simulation mostly form mixed couple puddles, there should be more altruist deaths than coward deaths overall, unless we see a disproportionately low amount of one altruist four coward puddles.

Due to the swingy nature of the early generation's impact on the whole, and the complex series of circumstances that need to happen for either gene to eclipse the other, I'd be really interested to see what this simulation looks like with much larger starting populations. It would be also be worth experimenting with a bias for altruists to pick altruist partners and cowards to pick coward partners, or to enforce that blobs pair off to reproduce at a fixed rate relative their share of the total population, rather than leaving it to pure chance. If trying to represent a large population, either the puddle families are split geographically and more likely to mingle with their own kind purely based on relative location, or the gene is spread more evenly, and a fixed ratio would do better to estimate whole populations dramatically larger than the sample size.

This is very misleading. Running is not cowardly - it's logical. Drawing attention to yourself is just stupid. Once you're further away, alerting others makes sense. In real life, most people will scream AND run anyway. And of course, the simulation leaves out all kinds of other subtle options, like hiding, using weapons, learning to avoid predators, passing on information to others, etc.

Very little can be gleaned from such research - the results are predictable given the limitations (yelling saves people but kills the person who yelled). And the words used - cowardice/altruism - are emotional and unjustified.

There is a flaw in your reasoning. There is absolutely no reason to expect that in any given species there would always be 3 offspring who barring being eaten in a single situation where they encounter a predator would survive to adulthood and also have 3 offspring. It is overwhelmingly optimistic to expect two parents to have 3 viable offspring who would then only encounter one single life threatening situation in their entire childhood or that that life threatening situation would benefit from either altruistic or cowardly behavior. This certainly is not true of humans or just about any other species I can think of. On the other side of the coin you have schooling fish where group cowardice is used to run and simultaneously confuse predators. In such an environment the altruistic behavior of swimming into the predators mouth would not even remotely have the effect of eliminating this danger for its siblings long enough for them to reproduce.

The point is that these results would change drastically if you removed or added even a single sibling from each generation. Or if you even presented the opportunity for the predator to attack them 2 or 3 times during their childhood before they could reproduce.

I would like to see a simulation with diploid genetic structure, where there is a chance of mutation that can happen to one of most of the different values used, one of which is dominance.

This experiment could perhaps be better tested with another scenario, but I will use the scenario and base attributes off of what was used in the video.

Each gene would have a set of attributes representing its likelihood of yelling vs fleeing, of surviving yelling/fleeing/staying etc. Each gene would also have a dominance value. If both genes have the same dominance value the blobs attributes will be the average of the attributes of each of its genes. If on the other hand one gene have a higher dominance than the other the blob will only use the attributes of the dominant gene.
When reproducing, each child blob would get one of each of its parents 2 genes, but at the same time have a set chance (let's say 10% for example) for one of the attribute values associated with one of the genes to be either increased or decreased by 5% (or 1 for non procentuental attributes such as dominance).

I think this would be an interesting experiment, since you could see genes develop themselves, but it could get somewhat hard to track the results on a higher scale experiment. On top of that, the dominance attribute as well as even the diploid genetic structure might not even make a big difference for the experiment. Something like what Primer did in the video Simulating Natural Selection might thus simply be a better version of the same general experiment.
But if you would still like to try it, a good way to make it a bit simpler to track would be to choose 3 attributes to either be the only attributes eligible for mutation or be the only ones visually tracked. A good way to track this would be to have them be represented by the red, blue and green values of the color of the blobs or alleles. (When using diploid genetic structure and dominance, blob color could be split in the middle to show each gene, since mixing the colors could give an inaccurate idea of what genes are in the gene pool.) Although not perfect, this would allow a for a bit better visual representation of the developed genes.

It would be interesting to see what would happen if you make the non yelling blobs also have some chance added to them. Let's say there are 2 states a blob can get to when the predator appears: staying and running. Running has a 95% chance of surviving and 5% of dieing, while staying has a 5% chance of surviving and a 95% chance of dieing. A blob who yell stays, while making it's siblings run, and a blob who flee runs, while making it's siblings stay.
The result might just be the same as with the guaranteed chance, but it'd be interesting to see.

The eqation for the expected gain is not correct, here is my solution:
The probability of gaining 1 Altruictic (-1A; +2A) = Fa + (1 - Fa) / 4
The probability of gaining 1 Selfish (-1A; +1A + 1S) = (1 - Fa) / 2
The probability of gaining 2 Selfish (-1A; +2S) = (1 - Fa) / 4

*The term (1 - Fa) / 4 is the probabality that both other siblings are either AA or SS
*The term (1 - Fa) / 2 is the probabality that at least one of the other siblings is selfish

SO the expected gain for Fa = 0.5 (initial condition) is:
= f+(1-f)/4 - (1-f)/2 - 2*(1-f)/4; f=0.5 which is +0.125
But once the fraction of altructic blobs goes below 0.43 the gain flips and becomes negative

Therefore I would assume a little bit more of the simulations should end with Selfish blobs going extinct but there should also be alot where altruictic will go extinct

I noticed it wasn't mentioned but... this reminds me of guessing what sex peoples sibling's are.

boy/girl is ~50%. If you pick randomly 100 girls that each have a single sibling, and you assumed their siblings are half boys half girls, you'd be wrong. The odds of a girl's sibling being another girl is less than 50%.Why? Because you chose only girls at the start.

Let's assume two children households.. 25% boy boy, 25% girl girl, 50% mix. And you only looked at girls. So all boy/boys are not included. Of the remainder, 2/3 mix, 1/3 girl/girl.

Back to the initial query, you should expect way more non-matching alleles than matching. In situations with mixed parents, your altruistic siblings are more likely to have coward siblings and be saving them even if the gene frequency is at 50/50. Which shifts your EVs and honestly, gives you the results you ended up getting.

That is the mistake you made with your calculations. The odds of a sibling isn't 0.5 x f. It is less than that because you have to include the fact only altruistic genes perform the altruistic action and you're ignoring coward/coward sibling pairs.

I think the Cowardice allele will actually do surprisingly well in the sexual reproduction simulation. My thinking is that the altruism gene is a 100% self-fatality if it spots the plant, whereas the cowardice gene is a 100% survival rate if it spots the predator instead. In the cases where the cowardice gene spots a predator, it will run and save itself, leaving 2 individuals to die (might be two altruistic ones, which are enemies and which the cowardice gene WANTS to die, or they could be friendly cowardice genes. Doesn't really matter though, since that cowardice gene has survived to go on and create potentially three more cowards. This means that, in practice, there's going to be a higher likelihood of there being at least one coward parent, meaning that there's a significant chance of proccing at least one coward, replacing the parent coward (who presumably dies after breeding if I understand the sim right) but also a chance to get pure gravy, if there's a second or third coward.

Ultimately, as the altruists gamble on being able to save maybe-altruist siblings to propagate their gene, there are simply going to be cowards getting free passes to bone-town. At the very least it's going to be VERY tough for the coward gene to ever truly fully die out.

FWIW there's another mistake in your vid, in your probability calculation.
You started off with "one parent definitely has the gene", but you cannot do that since that involves selecting a parent based on the feature you seek, and that would skew the distribution. (See: Monty Hall Paradox). The proper way is saying that with rate f^2 both parents are orange, with rate 2f (1-f) only one of them is; going from rates to posterior probabilities, we get f/(2-f) probability of both parents being orange, and (2-2f)/(2-f) probability of only one being thus, which leads to probability of an offspring having an orange gene being 1/(2-f), instead of (f+1)/2 like you calculated.

I think an easier and less abstract way of looking at it is thinking of saving a blob with the competing allele as a cost, and adding it to the equation. The cost would now be the life of the altruist blob that yells, plus 0.5 probability of a sibling inheriting the other parent´s allele multiplied by the frequency of the cowardice allele (fc) multiplied by the number of siblings (2).
The cost would now look like this:
Cost = 1 + 2 x 0.5 x fc
If we add this to the general equation of the hamilton´s rule, we would get:
2 x (0.5 + 0.5 x fa) - (1 + 2 x 0.5 x fc)
=
2 x (0.5 + 0.5 x fa - 0.5 x fc) - 1
If we do some simple math, and knowing that:
2 x 0.5 - 1 = 0
we end up with the next expression as the hamilton rule for the altruist allele in this simulation:
"0.5 x fa - 0.5 x fc"
As you start (very logically :P) all your simulations with fa=fc, the expected value is zero. But if you started the simulation with 60% altruist blobs, and 40% cowards, then it would statistically favour the altruist behavior, as the expected value would be higher than zero.

PS: I started writing thinking both ways of looking at it were right, just another way of picturing the same idea, but now (and maybe I´m wrong) I think your explanation is flawed, as with this last example I used, the equation you used would ignore both fa and fc, therefore giving a expected value of 0, regardless of the initial frequencies of each of the alleles. I would appreciate if you could run a simulation changing the initial values of fa and fc, so we can see which one of us is right or not (I don´t have the knowledge or the computer to be able to run it myself :P).

Here's my longish but determined attempt to explain the probability behind why the haploid altruism experiment reached 50%...

Honestly it makes sense that the haploid altruism case would has equal chances of saving a like-sibling versus saving a non-like sibling, with the only difference being that it means one parent is guaranteed to be altruistic. However to counteract the benefit of one parent being altruistic, every blob not saved is actually a blob saved for the competing gene, which muddies its numbers as a whole; rather than having one less on their team, putting a different of 1 between the groups, it also saves an enemy, making that deviating amount twice that (or 2).
A cowardice blob has a 100% chance of saving itself if its the one spotting the situation.

Throwing together scenarios for two altruistic (A) parents, two cowardice (C) parents, mixed parents with an altruistic blob spotting the threat, and finally mixed parents with a cowardice blob finding the parents, the total chances of survival for each are 50%. I used a spreadsheet to roughly figure this out and did my best to explain it below:

A/C parents, A-blob spotter (+0 A):
There's a chance to gain 2 living A-blobs, gain 1 A-blob (and 1 C-blob), or gain 0 (2 C-blobs).
It can do an average of 0 as every non-A blob is definitely a C-blob. In this instance, it helps both sides equally.

A/A parents, A-blob spotter (+6 A):
The A-blob is guaranteed to always save an A-blob, but more specifically, there's a value of 6 counting the gene pairings between two parent 1 genes, two parent 2 genes, or a mix of the two.
That's three scenarios accounted for, but all happen to have the same genes.

C/C parents, C-blob spotter (+3 C):
The C-blob will always run and always sacrifice it's siblings. While it loses two C-blobs each time, it is keeping one and isn't saving any for the A-blobs.
I noted this as a total of 3 as in all three mixtures of parental genes, regardless of outcome, the C-blob saves itself.

A/C parents, C-blob spotter (+3 C):
Just as with C/C parents, the C-blob spotter saves itself in all scenarios, making for a count of 3.

Comparing the total of 0+6=6 for the A blobs, and 3+3=6 for the C-blobs, they equally share a chance given their potential gene distributions to themselves and their affect (or lack-thereof) on their competing gene. Considering these are the only two genes being accounted for, their contribution to themselves and each other play a part in both runs.

Also for anyone who read this far, sorry for how poorly explained this was. It looks about as bad in the thrown-together excel spreadsheet I made to count the benefits towards both teams. But had fun looking into it myself and sharing my thoughts.

The Flaw in the Logic is that you Forgot to Factor in the Competition.
You only Look at the Altruists Chances but Forget to have these Chances Compete to the Cowards.


Worst Case Scenario. On First Round you Delete 1/3 of the Altruism Blobs and 2/3 of the Cowardice Blob.
Leaving them at a 2 to 1 Ratio.
So on Round 1. Indeed you get a Big Boost for Altruism.

But then 2 Blobs go to Mate. Now. Here it already gets tricky.
1/3 vs 2/3 mixing means that the Altruism Blobs will have some more Parents that stay Cowards entirely. While the Cowards actually have a higher Chance to Mix their Cowardice with Altruism. This is of course not accurate. But lets assume you end up with 2/10 Cowards, 4/10 Mixed and 4/10 Sacrificing.

And here we get to the Big Change.
In a Mixed Litter. The Coward Blob will Always Continue Home to Produce Offspring.
No matter what happens. The Coward Blob will never Die out in a Mixed Litter because he either is Saved by himself or by his Brother.

The Altruist however always Dies. Regardless of him Saving another Altruist or a Coward.

This means that the Cowards will Steadily keep Mixing into the Altruists. Reducing the Purely Altruist Families which are Providing the Biggest Gain. And Increase the amount of Mixed Families.
The Cowards do the same as Coward and Coward will lose Numbers automaticly.

Meaning both Parties try to move towards Mixed Families.

And here we come to the next problem.
You Choose Litters of 3 with a 50% chance on Mixed. Meaning you are very likely to have 2 vs 1 in each Litter.
So by Default. An Altruist has a Chance of Saving either 1 Altruist and 1 Coward. Or 2 Cowards. He will almost never Save 2 Altruists in 1 Litter.

Which means your Final Calculation looks Different as the Altruist in a Mixed Litter will have a Cost of 1 and a Gain of 1. Meaning his Best Case Scenario is a Net Neutral and the Worst Case Scenario is Net Negative 1
The Coward Blob in the Meantwime Plays on your Numbers. Because a Mixed Litter will usually have Max 2 Coward Blobs. So his Maximum Cost is almost Always 1.
(Rare case where a Mixed Parent Pair may Produce 3 Cowards)
Because if he Runs he loses one other Coward Sibling. His Potential however is 2 because the 1 Altruist might save them.
So his best Case is 2 Cowards Survive (Saved by Altruist)
His worst Case is 1 Coward Survives (The one that Runs away)

So his Scenario is a Net Positive of 1 or Bigger.

Thanks to this the Cowards will Never Die Out. As they keep being Saved by the Altruist which in turn is actually Likely to Die Out Quickly because the more the Population is Mixed. The more the Cowards gain an Advantage to their Survival and the more the Altruist gains an Disadvantage to his own Survival.

There are certainly a lot of different things you could check.  One, you could stop assuming that eugenics is true and that there IS an 'optimal genome' by introducing catastrophic environmental change (probably easiest to simulate by changing the role of a gene to its opposite).  Two, you could add in outwardly self-destructive but NOT altruistic cases (to my knowledge this has not been researched in Prisoner's Game type situations; they've never looked to see what happens overall if there are individuals which actively sabotage even themselves which I always felt was a shortcoming).  Three, and one I would really like to see, add an actual lifespan and possibly even pre-reproductive and post-reproductive segments.  Humans are the only species with a notable post-reproductive lifespan for females exclusively, so possibly even try seeing the effects on limiting this to only one sex.  Is waiting longer until puberty beneficial?  I know that shorter overall lifespans are actually preferred by evolution, that's been tested both in simulation and in bacterial cultures, but I'm not aware of changing reproductive windows.  Then of course you could add sexual selection competition or sperm competition... so many options.  I think the catastrophic environmental change, however, really NEEDS to be included because that is one of the primary drivers of all evolution.  There is good reason we don't see monocultures.  They go extinct as soon as one mutates a way to deal with the waste they produce, which confers on it an advantage that, by definition, can not exist in the host.  And catastrophic environmental change like a virus or parasite would cut through the "perfect" population like a hot knife through empty air.

Okay, so the problem is that the altruistic sibling is certainly dead. In the case with sexual reproduction, it introduces the possibility the siblings will not have the same allele unlike the asexual case where siblings always did.

Since we know the altruistic blob will die, the odds aren't actually 50/50. We have to account for the possibility that both blobs are altruistic, not just the remaining one. I don't know the exact numbers, but this change leads to altruism being a disadvantageous trait for the holder.

I'm not really good with statistics and stochastic but I've got the gut feeling that there were other mistakes:
A = Altruism, C = Coward
1. I feel like the probability for the sibling, and therefore the expected value, should be different:
There are 4 possible combinations of pairs (AA),(AC),(CA),(CC), so when ignoring the order we have the cases {A,A}, {A,C}, {C,C}
with f_A the chances of the combinations are therefore: P({A,A})=f_A^2, P({C,C})=(1-f_A)^2, P({A,C})=2*f_A(1-f_A)
So when we know that one parent is A, shouldn't the probabilities for the Other Parent be: A: P({A,A})/(P({A,A})+(P({A,C})))=f_A/(2-f_A) ?
so with f_A=50%: 1/3

Does this simulation account for the fact that an altruistic individual's efforts would inevitably benefit any cowards in their group? This means any coward that's in a group with at least one altruist is automatically guaranteed to live, and the majority of groups will have at least one altruist who is very likely to die. To me this suggests that, without some external influence on the frequency of altruism, it actually SHOULD go extinct most of the time. On average a group will have at least 1 coward and 1 altruist, and any groups that satisfy this average will see all cowards live and 1 altruist probably die. The only way a coward has a chance of dying is if they're in a group of nothing but cowards, in which case at least 1 is still almost guaranteed to live and there's a decent chance 2 could. If a group has all altruists then there's a guarantee 2 will live with a chance of all 3 living, which is better than a group of nothing but cowards would do on average, but I don't see how those outliers would make a big enough difference to even things out, let alone allow altruism to thrive. Selfishness would average out to be the more beneficial strategy since it guarantees your survival as long as an altruist is around and still gives you a fighting chance otherwise. The bigger a "group" gets, the more you would see this impact things; for instance if we assume it's a community and they work together outside of their own families, this almost guarantees the survival of ALL cowards in the entire community while also guaranteeing some altruists will die, which assures cowardice will win out over time.

The only way I see to change this is to add in peer pressure. This would explain why humans have adapted so much better for working together than most animals, because we have the ability to convince each other to change. A coward can be convinced that working together is beneficial, and they may even become altruistic themselves over time.

I came up with a slightly different explanation of the problem that's ultimately the same idea but doesn't rely on reasoning about the population as a whole: when you're sacrificing yourself and gambling that your siblings will carry on your altruistic allele, if you're wrong, then the cost (or damage you're causing) is actually more than just your life; the fact that you've actively saved competing alleles is also hurting your altruistic allele, and it happens with exactly the right frequency to cancel out the benefit that comes from not-identical-by-descent.

The error behind the prediction (and why Hamilton's rule qualifies only direct descents) is tied to two things:

[1] Only the expected value for the 'altruistic' allele (let's call it A) was considered. The 'cowardice' allele (let's call it C) also benefits from the altruistic action. Specifically, the externality benefit for C by A's action is 2(1-p) - 0, where the p is the probability of the 2nd parent to have allele A (since one parent must have A for the sacrifice to exist). The cost is 0 because the sacrifice is A, not C. Given that p is 0.5 + 0.5(fA), the expected externality of A's action for C is (1 - fA), where fA is the fractional incidence of A. Let's call this VC (value to C).

Since fA cannot be more than 1, (1 - fA) must be more than 0. This results in net benefit for C as well.

For comparison, the net value for A is 2(p) - 1, which translates to simply fA. Let's call this VA (value to A).

Note that the sum of both values is +1, which is the net benefit of the sacrifice regardless of allele.

[2] The population cap was not considered in the calculation of expected value. In the past, it did not matter as one allele has net benefit, and another has net loss. This is still true for families with purely C (which will die off due to negative EV). However, the actions of A, both A and C benefit. And since they later compete for houses, both cannot benefit (due to the limit), so the loss from not finding the house must decrease the expected value. Without knowing how the blobs behave without a house (die off or only without reproduction), the expected value cannot be derived. But knowing equal competition and zero growth, we can infer/guess that A will proliferate if net benefit for A > net benefit for C, and C will proliferate if the otherwise is true.

Both insights lead to an interesting observation.

VC = 1 - fA
VA = fA
with a net value of +1 regards of allele

If fA = 0.5, VA = VC (if population of A is 50%, neither proliferates)
If fA < 0.5, VA < VC (if population of A is lower than 50%, C proliferates, decreasing fA further)
If fA > 0.5, VA > VC (if population of A is higher than 50%, A proliferates, increasing fA further)

By the sacrificial action of A, not only is it possible for C to benefit more than A, the 50%-50% proportion is also an unstable solution (i.e. deviating from this ratio in either direction will push the scenario further away from this ratio over time / simulation cycles). It would also explain why we see a lot of extinction events of both A and C in the multiple simulation graph!

[This calculation does not consider the self-extermination of pure C families, which simply leads to more house vacancies for the A / A+C families, allowing the effect of A's sacrifice on both A and C be dominant.]

[Addenum]
In the scenario with 95% chance of death on A's action, net value are recalculated as follows.
VA = fA + 0.05
VC = 1 - fA

Allele C may have an advantage if initial population of A is lower than 47.5%. We could test this.

[Addenum 2]
Suppose 100% death on sacrifice, but each pair of parents have 4 offsprings instead of 3.
By this model, Allele A has the advantage if initial population of A is above 33.3%.

Suppose 100% death on sacrifice, but each pair of parents have only 2 offsprings instead of 3.
By this model, Allele A will always die out (VA > VC if fA > 100%), but C will also die out soon after.

11:08 Correct me if I'm wrong here but I believe there's a mistake in the reasoning behind this equation.

for simplicity I'm just going to represent the altruistic gene and the unknown genes as A & U respectively.

for 2 siblings there are 4 possible combinations of genes:
AA AU
CU UU

We know that 1 sibling is altruistic meaning that the gene combination cannot be CC leaving us with 3 options.
AA AU
UA

of these 3 options, only 1 helps an altruistic gene meaning that the chance for the siblings to be identical by descent and altruistic is 1/3 NOT 1/2.

This means that the correct equation should be:
p =1/3 + (2/3)*fa
therefore when fa 0.5 at the start:
p = 1/3 + 2/3*1/2 = 4/6 = 2/3

13:15 "If you think there's a flaw in this reasoning, it's your turn to point it out."

I'm gonna take a shot in the dark and guess it's related to the Monty Hall problem. Specifically, the sacrificial allele of a group of siblings is a known quantity, and therefore the probability that the remaining two siblings are sacrificial alleles is no longer an independent variable. (E.g. flip two coins: if at least one of them shows up as heads, remove it and don't count it, now count the number of heads appear. You can only have 2 tails (25%), 2 heads (25%) and 1 tail x 1 head (50%), and if you always remove 1 head if it shows up, then you'll count 2 tails (25%), 1 tail (50%), and 1 head (25%), so you'll count 4x as many tails as heads.

14:47 "Anyways, take a minute to see if you can figure out the flaw."

To expand on the above. In the case of parent A and parent B both being altruists (the odds of which are a function of the broader population, so at the start its 0.5x0.5 = 25%), then all 3 children are altruists and so the EV of the trade is 2 - 1 = 1. But in the case of say parent A and parent B having different alleles (one coward and one altruist), which occurs 50% of the time at the beginning of the simulation, if each allele has a 50% chance of passing on to one of the three siblings, this means there are 2^3 possibilities for alleles among the children: all 3 have it (1/8), any two have it (3/8), just one has it (3/8), and none have it (1/8). If we know a sacrificial allele exists (eliminating the outcome that none have it), and we know one of the sacrificial alleles always sacrifices itself, that means the probabilities for the remaining alleles other than the sacrificer are as follows: 2 copies (1/7), 1 copy (3/7), and 0 copies (3/7). This means the expected value of the sacrifice is +1 x (1/7), +0 x (3/7), and -1 x (3/7) = -(2/7) when parent A and B are different.

So under different population ratios, the EV can definitely dip below 0 and into the negatives. This renders the EV of altruism strongly dependent upon the random outcomes of the first few cycles in any given run of the simulation.

I see two problems here:
1) The one mentioned - failing to account for the cowardly alleles when calculating the probability.
2) Going broke - that +1/6 EV in the coin example is only true under the assumption that you have sufficient coins to play through a losing streak. That is, if your pot ever hits zero you're done no matter what the expected value is in the long term - your long term is cut short once that happens. (And similarly this would become likely in the simulation if the population started with significantly less than 50% altruistic alleles.)

An alternative way to consider what went wrong with prediction is to think of it as a Monty Hall problem. Lets consider the 50/50 population split at first. What are the chances that both parents of the altruist are altruists? You might want to say 1/4, because AA, CA, AC, and CC pairings are all equally likely in this population. But the fact that the current blob is altruist means at least one parent had to be. So the CC pairing is not possible, with other three still equally likely, meaning odds of AA pairing are actually 1/3, and probability that one of the parents is a coward is 2/3. Likewise, if two parents are different, what are the odds that all 3 blobs are altruists? As before, it is 1/7 instead of 1/8, since we discard the all cowards possibility. This means that the average benefit for sounding alarm is 2 * 1/3 for both parents being altruists plus (2 * 1/7 + 1 * 3/7 + 0 * 3/7) * 2/3 if one of the parents is a coward. This works out to 2/3 * (1 + 5/7) = 8/7, which is still somewhat above 1. So at 50/50 population, altruism is beneficial. In general, the average benefit works out to [2 * fa^2 + (5/7) * 2 * (fa - fa^2)] / [fa * (2 - fa)]. This is equal to 1 exactly when fa = 4/11, or about 36.4%. If the fraction of altruists drops bellow that value by chance, it will have a tendency to decrease. Because there is a lot of fluctuation in this simulation, in part because the benefit to cost is so close to 1:1 for a large swath of population distributions, quite a few simulations will lead to altruism gene going extinct.

The only issue i see with this in a real world setting is that animals face life and death situations everyday yet it takes months or years to reach sexual maturity. As far as herbivores go, there arent any "altruistic" deer, antelope, or cows or anything of that sort. While wildebeest could easily wipe the lion population via teamwork and altruism they do not, which makes me think that this setup is flawed as it should take multiple encounters with predators before a single baby is spawned.

I feel like in the animal kingdom altruism generally gets wiped out except for rare instances. Personally, i think altruism has more to do with intelligence and comfortability in surviving a situation rather than genetics, like how whales will help out other animals because they are confident that they wont be killed.

Edit: to add to that, i dont think there is evidence of humans being genetically altruistic to the degree that they will sacrifice their lives so that others will live and reproduce. Unless socially taught to do so, most people run from any sort of danger or life threatening situation. Even in religion the concept of pure altruism and "suffering for another" is largely linked back to Christianity and is a moral system that must be taught and is not universal amongst all cultures.

The only animals i can think of that is hardwired to die to save others would ants, termites, and bees. Certain species of termites have "defense" termites that literally explode to coat the tunnels with sticky liquid that slows down attackers and gives the rest of the colony enough time to escape. Outside of that, i cannot think of any animals where they genetically are designed to sacrifice themselves to save others of their species.

I'm at 13:26 right now and a flaw I think I can see is that the blob's own survival isn't the only factor here. The death of an altruistic blob is positive for the cowardly blob, as that frees up more houses for reproduction. The death of a cowardly blob is positive for an altruistic blob (or at least for their altruistic genes) as well. Thus, the cost of acting altruistically is also dependent on the frequency of the genes *as well as the housing situation*.

Let's say houses are exceedingly rare and there's just one free spot in a house left:
We look at a blob named "Marvin" and his puddle of blobs.
Assume that Marvin's gene (whatever it is) has a frequency of p.
Then probability of Marvin having 2 siblings with the same genes is (1/2+p/2)^2=(1+2p+p^2)/4, the probability of both 1 sibling with his genes and one with the other genes is (1/2+p/2)(1/2-p/2)*2=(1-p^2)/2 and the probability that both his siblings have different genes is (1/2-p/2)^2=(1-2p+p^2)/4.
Let's now say Marvin is eating at a tree with his puddle and sees a predator.
Whatever happens, just one of the three siblings can procreate in a house. If Marvin doesn't sacrifice himself, his gene will thus definitely procreate once, but if he does sacrifice himself, it only has a chance of (1+2p+p^2)/4+(1-p^2)/4=(1+p)/2 to procreate. Thus it is always better not to sacrifice yourself in this scenario - it is better to be cowardly.

As a population of only altruistic blobs would balloon quickly (2 pairing altruistic blobs make 3 altruistic blobs, out of which at most 1 can die per cycle, meaning the reproduction rate is always above 1), a dire housing situation is quickly to be expected and thus we can in fact expect the cowardly to do well. As the population of cowardly blobs increases (and depending on the number of evil trees), the housing situation might relax and the altruistic blobs might do better again, and thus a balance would be struck.

If the number of evil trees is not high enough to shrink even a population of only cowardly blobs, we can expect those cowardly blobs to do great (as the population will never shrink, there will always be a housing shortage). In that case, the altruistic blobs will completely die out, but the cowardly blobs will still be able to fill all houses each cycle. For this scenario the proportion of evil trees has to be less than 1/2. To see this, solve this inequality for the reproductive rate (average number surviving offspring produced by a pair of cowardly blobs): r=3*(1-p)+1*p>2 <=> 3-2p>1 <=> p<0.5

If the more than half of all trees are evil, you will get an equilibrium between cowardly and altruistic blobs because with only cowardly blobs the population will shrink, and as soon as the housing situation relaxes, being altruistic is again the optimal strategy).

I would assume in general systems (i.e. real evolution), sacrificing yourself for your family in situations with restricted resources is also not always optimal.

Edit: Okay so I continued the video, and my analysis was completely wrong. Not having to consider those blobs who are not identical by descent makes my whole point moot. I'll have to do the rigorous derivation mentioned in the video, though, to see this for myself. In the meantime, I will leave this comment up for posterity.

I feel like there's a much simpler way that I (perhaps incorrectly) understand why the outcome was what it was.

Each generation can be one of four combinations of altruist and non-altruist:
3-0, 2-1, 1-2, or 0-3

presuming they run into a predator:
- 3 altruists: 2 altruists survive; this gives altruists an advantage
- 2 altruists: 1 of each survives after the altruist sacrifices themselves; this outcome is exactly 50/50
- 1 altruist: 2 non-altruists survive after the altruist sacrifices themselves; this gives non-altruists an advantage
- 0 altruists: none survive; this group of entirely-non-altruists removes itself

The next question is, "okay, how many of each of these groups do we start with?". Luckily, statistics for "how likely am I to have three boys in a row" is a pretty googleable answer; each above outcome is 25% likely, because we are not falling into the gambler's fallacy.

Therefore, we should start with an equal distribution of all 4 types of family group, leading to a child generation that has these outcomes:
1/4: the 0-altruist group deletes itself
1/4: the 1-altruist group results in a gain for non-altruists
1/4: the 2-altruists group breaks even
1/4: the 3-altruists group results an the exact same gain but for altruists, perfectly negating the 1 altruist group

As such, given enough mirrored simulations... the outcomes will be... 50/50. Precisely.

Before I see the ending and guessing the mistake:

The probabilities look weird. If B is 2, as in saving 2 blobs that have the altruistic gene, then p is the probability that yelling will save 2 blobs with the desired gene. If both parents are Altruistic (A) then the probability that yelling saves 2 blobs is 100%. If the probability of one parent's gene is independent of the other then the probability of both parents being altruistic is f_A × f_A where f_A is the frequency of the altruism in the population. So the probability of saving 2 blobs and the parents being A is (f_A)^2. After doing similar math for parents with A and not A, I came to the conclusion that p = f_A. I'll watch the rest of the video and see how wrong I am.

There is one other very small thing in the expected value equations, which is that if for all of the blobs it is 50-50, the first parent is one of those, so the chances for both parents to have it is slightly less than 50-50. For example in a pool of 1000 blobs in total to start, starting at 50-50, given one parent having that allele already, the chances that the other one would have it as well would be 499/999, not 500/1000. It's a very small thing with a very small effect on the EV, but it is still a slight inaccuracy.

Another intuitive way to think why blue and orange numbers even out is that due to normalization after each step (housing limit) killing the opponent allele (equal to letting it die while one runs)  is actually a viable strategy. So the blue's EV ranges from -1 to 0 depending on population composition, BUT the expected number of killed oranges ranges from 0 to 1, wheras orange strategy never kills blue. Interestingly enough, both blue and orange get better results the higher percentage of population is orange. So the orange strategy focuses on thriving its own kind, while blue focuses on killing the opponent.

you get pairs "aa" with probability f^2 (f is shorthand for f_a here), "ab" with 2f(1-f) and "bb" with (1-f)^2;
then pair "ab" yields descendants "aaa", "aab", "abb", "bbb" with probabilities 1/8, 3/8, 3/8, 1/8 correspondingly;
after predator "aab" yields "ab" with probability 2/3 and "b" with probability 1/3
and so on for every case...
in the end final fraction is something like 2f(1+f)/(f^2+f+2), which is >f everywhere except 0 and 1, although difference isn't that significant --- 5% tops. Prediction at 13:30:





The cowardly and altruistic alleles are playing a zero-sum game. A gain for one is a loss for the other. The chance of saving a cowardly allele should have been taken into account as negative benefit.

ExpectedBenefit - ExpectedCost = ExpectedValue

The benefit of saving an altruist (Baltruist) is 1 and the benefit of saving a coward (Bcoward) is -1.

ExpectedBenefitSibling = Baltruist*p + Bcoward*(1-p)
ExpectedBenefitSibling = p - (1-p)
ExpectedBenefitSibling = 2*p - 1

There are two siblings, so
ExpectedBenefit = 2*ExpectedBenefitSibling
ExpectedBenefit = 4*p - 2

Because p = 0.5 + 0.5 * fa
ExpectedBenefit = 4*(0.5 + 0.5 * fa) - 2
ExpectedBenefit = 2 + 2*fa - 2
ExpectedBenefit = 2*fa

Since the sacrificer dies,
ExpectedCost = 1

Therefore,
ExpectedBenefit - ExpectedCost = ExpectedValue
2*fa - 1 = EV

For altruism to be beneficial:
EV > 0
2*fa - 1 > 0
2*fa > 1
fa > 1/2

If the frequency of the altruism allele drifts above 50%, altruism will be beneficial. If it drifts below 50%, altruism will be harmful. I predict altruism will win half the time and cowardice will win half the time.




Edit: my prediction wasn't quite right.

I assumed
ExpectedValue = Altruistic Allele Increase - Cowardice Allele Increase

But actually
ExpectedValue = Increase in Fraction of Altruistic Alleles

Each strategy won around half the time like I predicted, but the altruism allele doesn't become beneficial when it drifts above 50%, and it doesn't become harmful when it drifts below 50%.

The issue is that consciousness or “environment” (which is just perception) governs genetic expression and therefore the likely behavior. This feedback loop is something people experience but are not victim to, and so there is no deterministic setting for the evolution of a population’s behavior given an environment unless that environment is heavily constrained. Fortunately, our planet Earth is not a constrained environment and so many different developments of consciousness can occur. In fact all of evolution is an organic and creative expression of consciousness not necessarily genes. In this sense a species can choose to evolve in a particular direction by slowly changing the environments in which they express themselves in an objective sense or by altering their perspective. This complexity is cannot be modeled, and, is the reason for selflessness vs selfishness which has nothing to do with the physical state of the world but instead the perceptual state of the consciousness of the group.

Why are you fixated on predictive explanations over hindsight explanations? Maybe I misunderstood that part of the video where you explained your feelings... but predictive explanations are almost always useless, and hindsight is all that matters. Nature is so mysterious, and can get complex. None of us are born with understanding it, we have to learn through experimenting with nature. It seems to be a matter of pride to predict the result before experimenting, or at least an anticipated dopamine rush. I think you're setting yourself up for disappointment this way. Most guesses will be wrong. As long as you understand why nature behaves as it does after the experiment, that is all that matters. It's ok to be wrong: it happens all the time and it's the best way to learn.

at 18:10, i think you ignored a key factor. The 0.5 x fa is not something you can ignore. If fa is greater than 0.5, then on average you will be saving altruistics more than cowardices, and vice versa, relative to the percentage of the total population. This isnt just a flip of a coin, or else all of your examples would have just stayed near 50/50. This is a self reinforcing loop, just like the last ones, where the type of reinforcing (positive or negative) is a flip of a coin at the first few generations.

I.E, im willing to bet that if you ran this simulation again, with altruistics being above 50% frequency, then they would more often then not still become dominant. This is because the 50/50 of being a positive or negative self reinforcing loop would now be skewed towards positive at the start.

In fact, i would go as far as to state that if altruism starts at n% of the total population, you will have a n% chance of it becoming the dominant.

The population is essentially capped so being good and satisfying Hamilton's rule isn't about population growth but rather the percentage difference. This means we need to look at the EV of other groups in relation, if 2 groups have a EV of 1.5, they would both grow at a rate of 1.5 per generation on average. But since the growth of one means less housing for the other, Hamilton's rule doesn't really equate. It's not about having a positive EV but rather a EV higher then the competition. And it's important to factor in the natural growth from no predators being present at certain trees as it changes the threshold for Hamilton's law being "positive". Another missed detail is that the cost is ALWAYS 1 as they die from old age, but not always get a benefit. Hamiltons rule is about population size growth, otherwise death would never be a cost.

Case 1: This is mostly unrelated, but it's to establish an important part for later. No altruism thrives because of the effect of predators. For no predator in tree: P(negative rate of predators) * (P(100% siblings)B(+3 spawned) - C(1 dies of age)) + P(rate of predators) * (B(0 spawn)P(100% siblings) - C(1 eaten)). Animation looks roughly like 1 in 5 have a predator for 0.8(3-1) + 0.2(0-1) for a total net of +1.4. For all future comments, since its the same regardless of Altruist/Coward and the spawn rate doesn't change, the part for no predators is always a default 1.6. Note taht as long as the EV on a predator level event is above -1.6, Hamilton's rule would say population growth.

Potential control study: To look truly at if competition is what drives Hamilton's rule, change the predator spawn chance to 2/3rds which is the equilibrium point. There should be no net gain for blobs that "thrive" in that environment, and they should die off at anything more.

Case 2: Altruism thrives over Cowards. Important detail is that only one of them notices the predator, so if coward, not all run away. If we take the extended Hamilton's rule that factors in the chance of predators, then its

Altruism: no predator in tree: 1.6 + rate of predator * (B(6 spawn from survivors, average at 2 per blob)P(100%) - C(2 from old age, 1 from eaten for 1 average)) for a net total of 1.8.

Cowards: no predator in tree: 1.6 + rate of predator * (B(3 spawn from survivor, average 1 per blob)P(100%) - C(1 from old age, 2 from eaten for 1 average)) for a net total of 1.6.

Potential control study: Here the cowards die off despite having a positive EV. If a simulation was ran with the coward gene only, they would thrive in that area and reach population cap. Even though they die off when Altruists are near. The lack of housing is what kills cowards as the Altruists take more and more spots in relation to the Cowards.

Case 3: Even battle between the two with genetic diversity. I'll only be looking at starting conditions since we really only care if it goes up or down. We now have 4 situations to check, predator with a coward scout, predator with a altruist scout and no predator with both. No predator doesnt change since its per blob, same distinction to both sides so it remains the same. So now we have to look at the reduced effect of altruists due to having cowards in the party and the amount of altruists lost when a coward scout has altruists in their puddle. Chance of a sibling being the same is 75%. 0.1 is the chance of the situation occurring, 50% chance of the right scout paired with a 20% chance of a predator. Also note the cost to team Altruist when an altruist scout meets a predator is 0.83 (1+0.75+0.75 average over 3 blobs) as some of the cost is paid in coward blobs

Altruism: no predator in tree: 1.6 + altruist scout 0.1(B(2 average)P(75%) - C(0.83)) + coward scout 0.1(B(0 all die)P(25%) - C(0.17) for a total EV of 1.7

Cowards: no predator in tree: 1.6 + coward scout 0.1(B(1 average)P(75%) - C(0.83)) + altruist scout 0.1(B(1 average)P(25%) - C(0.17) for a total EV of 1.7

Here we see that when you factor in the number that are saved by the other party and the reduced cost effect caused by not all members being the same, they have an equal EV which is why we see no average chance. The shared gene shouldn't matter in this kind of scenario where the difference between Br and Bp is irrelevant.

Hopefully this helps explain why Hamiltons rule stopped working, it was still correct but you were using the wrong variables. Its carefully hidden in the setup of the scenario where the natural growth caused by no predator trees can allow a positive EV to still die out, that the parents die after giving birth making the C always at max, evaluating the EV on a per group basis rather then an averaged out blob basis and by looking at circumstances for reversed outliers in the last case.

The calculation of probabilities at 13:00 is wrong. The starting case is 3/5 that the sibling shares the orange gene and the worst case is 1/3 that the sibling shares it. Why? Because the fact that the blob in question has the orange gene rules out the possibility of both parents having the blue gene. There are two cases where the parents have different genes and only one case where they have the same gene. The same logic then also applies to the cases where the parents have mixed genes.

As for the human situation:
The human biological reward system for altruism probably evolved while we lived in smaller, disconnected, family groups.

While there were some exchange of DNA, just like a pride of lions we lived in what would today be described as extended family groups, or later in history the more fomal klans.

While the family groups could foster general altruism, the klans used our social abilities to divide the world into "us" and "them", leading to nationalism and large scale war.

As can be seen with pets, our biological drive to help others is so strong it crosses species boundaries, which was beneficial when we accepted cats or domesticated wolfs, horses, cattle and other livestock and service animals. Even today people can form tight bonds with the sheep or the pig that will be slaughtered for food in six months, with no emotional scaring.

The question is, can we create a global community, where enough people look at others of our species not as competitors, but as cooperators?

We have the mental and emotional capacity to do this. We can calculate that everyone is better off if everyone cooperates, and we can design things like traffic flows so that even the selfish actions give the better result.

But can we keep crime in check (and by crime i include anything from theft and robbery to murder, terrorism and wars) without too many people sense they sacrifice more than they gain? And neutralizing those last people by other means, such as punishment for crimes.

Spoiler for the "network collaboration with no known relative". That is why we have an innate tribalism (leading into racism). Simple creatures try to collaborate more with people they recognize more similar to them (same skin colour, same language), as they are more likely to be closely related to them and sharing the same genes. With the evolution of social behaviour, memes (in Dawkins sense, not as a fanny picture) supplanted genes and we are getting to a shared altruism above tribalism and genetic.

After finishing the video:
I'm not exactly sure what's wrong with the above explanation, or even if it is wrong. I think it is getting at the underlying idea that saving a cowardly gene is actually a net loss because you are decreasing your own allele's frequency in the population. Similarly, letting an opposing allele get eaten actually increases your allele's frequency but doesn't require your allele to get any larger in number. I think the more intuitive expected value calculation could still work if you included the net gain and loss for BOTH alleles in every decision.

I could be wrong, but does altruism towards strangers maybe have something to do with Hamiltons rule?
What I mean is, you more often feel sympathy towards people that are "similar" to you, signifying that they share similar genes/alleles. By behaving altruisticly towards "similar" strangers it's not unlikely that you are promoting your own genes/alleles. This might not be a result of "clever" natural selection, but a side effect, i.e. the Altruism allele doesn't tell you to help siblings per se, as you don't really have a way to know instinctively who you're siblings are, instead it tells you to help people who are familiar to you (as siblings would be). This would have the side effect of you helping strangers who aren't actually related with you, but are "similar" and therefore seem familiar. I don't think this is the full explanation, but it might be a part of it and I just wanted to share it.

I think that a great situation to explore would be genes which change behaviour depending on which other genes are present. For example, Gene A with Gene B and Gene C makes some behaviour, but if any of the three are missing it doesn't present with the change. This type of linkage is common in pigmentation where you have a set of genes for enzymes which each catalyse a part of the process for synthesising a pigment but a failure in any one of these genes leaves you with the intermediate product. This means that a failure in Gene A may result in the original input being left, say a black pigment, but if Gene A works then the black is changed to green. If Gene B works it will convert to yellow, and Gene C would change to blue. Each step has a failure presentation which can be seen, but in behaviour it is not visible.

PREDICTION: The altruists will die off quickly in almost all cases. I'm assuming the starting case (50/50 population) and randomly choosing one sibling to notice the threat:

Half of the time an altruist notices the threat. In half of those cases the altruist has AC siblings and sacrifices themselves to save 1 A, breaking even. The other half of those cases involve an equal share of AA (expected value 1) and CC (expected value -1) encounters, which cancel each other out. The remaining 50% of encounters involve a coward noticing the threat. These all have zero payout to the altruists, but the cost is 0, 1 or 2 altruist deaths. Looking at all encounters, 25% of the time the expected value is -1, and 12.5% of the time the expected value is -2, giving us an overall expected value of -0.5 at the start. It will only get worse as the number of altruists falls.

In the original setup (14:11), the expected gain changes with the population. The expected gain of being altruistic is only positive when the population of altruists is greater than the population of cowards. It looks like there is an advantage to altruism when the population is an even split, but the data suggests there is not.

I can see two potential flaws to point out in the reasoning at 13:20.
1: Probability of shared genes
In the starting case with fa=0.5, .75 of the pairs will have at least one altruist. .25 will have two. Therefore, the chance of an altruistic partner, given you are an altruist, is 1/3. The same math applies to each sibling. plugging in 1/3 creates an unstable equilibrium. However, writing this down has made me realize that I was actually wrong, because there is twice the chance of being in the double pairs. Apparently 0.5 does equal 0.5. 0_o I am really overthinking this.

2: Probability of saving competitors
The difference between dying alone and saving one identical gene is that it also saves one competitor, which is a net 0. In general, you need to subtract the chance of competing genes (1-fa).
2p-(1-fa)-1, 2[p-(0.5-0.5fa)]-1, 2[fa]-1.
This would create an unstable equilibrium, with half becoming completely altruist and the others cowards. However, this solution doesn't sit right with me.

In conclusion, it must have something to do with accidentally helping competitors, because the net impact is what matters, not just the success of shared genes. I don't think my solution is exactly correct, so I'm not sure if it will actually be unstable or stable 50%.

"Hindsight explanations aren't worth as much."
On the contrary, they may be worth more than a prediction. Either you just didn't think enough beforehand, in which case you should have known better, but there's always the possibility of unknown unknowns: something you couldn't have known about beforehand. If something happens that you have no way to explain, then, unless the prior explanation is true, you now know for certain that there is something else involved.
If it works consistently well in theory, but fails in practice, the only logical explanation is that you're missing a component of the puzzle, which drives you to look deeper into variables that, as far as you knew at the time, had no impact on the outcome.
In other words, you may have just discovered something new.

I think another perspective to spot the mistake (and the way I spotted it), is to realise there is only a 1/3 chance that the analysis you did is relevant.

This is because each puddle has 3 blobs, so there is only a 1/3 chance that you are the one making the gamble.


To work out the chance of the gene thriving, you need to work out the chances for the whole puddle, meaning that you also need to calculate the chances that you get thrown to the predator by your cowardly sibling, or saved by an altruistic one.

Your analysis took it for granted that you get to make the life-or-death decision, but you do not always get to do so.

A much more intuitive explanation is that the value of saving a cowardly allele is not zero - it's negative. By saving it, it is now competing for resources with altruistic alleles.

The issue is that the altruists are sacrificing themselves to save selfish blobs. If a puddle has 1 altruist then it will die to save 2 selfish blobs. Even with 2 altruists, one dies to save 1 altruist and 1 selfish blob, which is worse than if the altruist just saved itself. So the altruism trait is only beneficial if all 3 of the blobs are altruists, which only happens 1/8 of the time.

I’ve always wondered at people who talk about ‘overpopulation’ but it’s not. We are on the precipice of a dramatic underpopulation problem and there won’t be enough young people around to take care of an ageing population.

We still have places like Africa and some Asian nations having ‘too many’ children. However, they’re being ‘educated’ on the matter just like previous ‘trouble spots’ India, China et al. Whom have dramatically reduced their birth rates recently.

To us, westerners, having 10-20 children was normal barely a century ago. Before child mortality rates were improved with basic hygiene practices, vaccinations, and antibiotics fixed all that.

We used to pump out children like a processing plant because we had to; they all kept dying before even reaching adolescence. But even today it still exists in these impoverished places like I mentioned; birth rates per mother is absurd.

The controversial thought being; how much effort do you put into an infant in such conditions? Being poor and little access to help, you know most of your children will die, so why be sad about the youngest ones dying? Why put effort, time, money, emotional investment before they even provide a return on your investment. Wouldn’t an older child be more sad to lose than a baby? An older child can work, you taught it to, it will hopefully soon care for you when you age. Just curious… if people could put themselves into that mental space - The ‘value’ of a child depending on its age/amount of investment. Rather than ‘aww why baby die? So sad!’

Also another thought; this ‘leave none behind’ mantra that seems to exist in, specifically, the USA military. You’ve seen it in film, you’ve perhaps even heard Medal of Honour true accounts of brave soldiers running back and getting themselves killed in vein attempt to save their fallen brothers. Or even just the corpses thereof.

It’s a noble thought. But does it really happen as often as portrayed in Hollywood film. Or foretold by every soldier in reality; ‘we won’t leave you behind! Ra!’

Then hear accounts of entire squad casualties because one soldier fell.

It certainly would raise my morale and I’d fight harder knowing this were true. I’d do it for the man beside me because he would for me too etc. ‘we’re better than the bad guys’ thought etc.

It’s just all crazy to me.

the reason why you have such variation in the different runs is because of Genetic drift. Because of the random assortment of mating pairs you will get large variations in the results. if you want to control for this either make it non random who reproduces with who or have a larger sample size with your blobs. The lower the breeding population the greater the selective force needs to be in order to reliably overcome genetic drift.

13:20 There are actually two issues with this.
11:37 is wrong: Since we don't know which of the parents has the altruism gene, there are 3 out of 4 base situations remaining: Rather than each parent either having the altruism gene, we are either in a situation where just parent A has the altruism gene, just parent B has it, or both have it. In the initial 50:50 configuration, for example, each of these scenarios has a 33% chance of occuring, and in two of those situations, the other parent does not have the altruism gene. Thus, the chance is not actually 0.5+0.5*0.5, but only 0.5+0.5*0.33.
Furthermore, recall that the limiting factor was housing space, and that any surviving blob without the altruism gene has a chance of finding a house and locking out a blob with the altruism gene. For this reason, it is actually not a completely neutral event for the altruism gene if a blob without the gene is saved; it becomes a strictly negative event for the gene. So when calculating the chance of saving a copy of the altruistic gene, we actually have to subtract the chance that the second saved blob pushes out a blob with the altruistic gene.

I still see an issue: you seem to assume that an altruistic blob always has both an altruistic and a cowardly sibling. But that would mean that the nest of mixed parents always has two altruistic children and only one coward. This is not a reasonable assumption! One should also take into account the possibility that a nest has only one altruist and two cowards. In this case, the altruist kid would sacrifice itself to save two cowardly siblings, thereby hurting the chances of the altruism allele. THAT is where a simulation could end up with only cowards.

Isn't there another problem with the way Hamilton's rule is used in the video? When calculating the Hamilton's rule, there is a hidden assumption that all altruistic blobs that survive make it to the next generation. That is not the case because of the house limit. Let's have the 5% survival chance for altruists, but also add a rule that coward blobs that run away copy themselves (for example) 5 times before returning to houses. This leaves the in-video Hamilton's rule calculation with a positive result, so altruists should take over, but we'd observe that they would usually go extinct instead. That is because the altruists that would survive food gathering would usually not be able to find a house and thus disappear.

@13:22, you've left out one sibling from consideration. Given an altruist population portion `f` (so I don't have to deal with the subscript `f_a`), and given the fact that one member of the triplet is an altruist, each sibling has a `(1 + f)/2` chance of being altruistic, so the full thing is, I think, 2 * (1 + f) / 2 * 1 + (1 + f)^2 / 4 * 2 - 1 = 1 + f + 1/2 + f + f^2 / 2 = 2.1 + 2f + 3.0f^2 (note the use of left-to-right seximal). Once again, the EV is still at least 0 (when they're all already dead), so I don't think this is really the problem, but it's what I noticed.

Here's another thing I noticed about the sexual-reproduction simulation, that isn't quite as math-based as your explanation. You're correct in your assertion that in a "puddle" with all-altruistic vs all-cowardly individuals, the altruistic gene does indeed hold the clear advantage. However, in a situation where a puddle has both alleles, cowards actually come out on top.

Consider a situation with one altruist and two cowards. Only one will notice the predator, and no matter what, the altruist always dies (either by sounding the alarm, or not getting alerted by the coward that noticed) and at least one coward survives (either by fleeing, or by being alerted by the altruist). Similarly, in a situation with two altruists and one coward, the coward always survives and at least one altruist always dies (sometimes both of them).

Like you said, this situation is very simplified, but I thought I would offer a more conceptual argument in favor of cowardice to counter your mathematical argument in favor of altruism. Perhaps they balanced each other out, causing the two alleles to even each other out in the long term.
