The four ways blobs can breed:
AxA, AxC, CxA, CxC.

AxA produces 2 Altruists.
AxC/CxA produces 1 Altruist and 1 Coward if an Altruis is alerted, and produces 1 Coward if a Coward is alerted (50 / 50 chance).
CxC produces 1 Coward.

So the total equation(big A/C is percentage of population, small a/c is avg gain per household/breeding pair):
A*A*2a + C*A*(a+2c) + C*C*c
at 100% A: = 2a
at 75% A: = 9 / 16 a + 7 / 16 c (9 to 7)
at 50% A: = 3 / 4 a + 3 / 4 c (1 to 1)
at 25% A: = 5 / 16 a + 15 / 16 c (1 to 3)
at 0% A: = c

While altruism produces a greater amount of offspring in total for the species, it doesn't dominate as hard as cowardice does. When cowardice is in majority it keeps altruism down, but while altruism is in majority it almost benefits cowardice more than it benefits altruism.

One important think to know about the expected value (EV) when applied to gambling is that it assumes infinite money and infinite people. Something that isn't true in the real world.

Imagine a population of 60 blobs that each have 1 coin.
They are smart blobs and calculate the EV as in the video (1/6) and see that it's positive,.
They think they are going to beat the dumb casino owner (assume he has 1 million coins).
Out of the 60 blobs who play the game in the video, 50 will leave having lost their coin, only 10 will have 7 coins after the first round.
The majority of blobs are loses and leave broken after first round.
In the second round, there is a 27% chance they will lose the next 7 rolls (5/6)^7. So maybe 3 of the blobs now have to leave empty handed, leaving only 7.
This repeats round over round, with some blob losing all his money.
Over time the probability of a losing streak that is greater than you money supply is 100%.
There are only 2 outcomes, all the blob lose their money and the casino gets all the money, or a blob will bankrupt the casino, and that blob then has all the money and effectively becomes the casino.

The casino always win, even on these 'losing' odds.

90% of this went over my head, but I'm going to say in the second simulation, after giving it a moment of thought, the blue ones are probably better off because of the fact that during EVERY interaction, one of them is guaranteed to survive. A blue one running away guarantees a blue draw from the next pool.

The orange one, however, has a chance to save two blue ones when it dies, effectively removing itself from the next draw.

So simply speaking, there is a 100% chance that a blue one will survive the encounter to put it's genes in for the next draw, and a >100% chance that an orange one will. The only way this wouldn't happen if there are absolutely no blue ones in the puddle, but that doesn't count as a loss to blue because there wasn't anything to lose anyway. Looking at this this way, it makes absolute sense why the blue one will eventually become dominant, despite the fact that it's sacrificing 2 to save 1.

13:25 predication: you should also consider the effects on the cowardice allele, and the effects of the cowardice action on both alleles:
at the start the chance of a coward being saved will be 0.25 by altruism, at best for altruism the chance of coward being saved by altruism will be 0, and at worst for altruism, the chance of coward being saved by altruism is 0.5, each of those times 2 (for 2 siblings) but at no cost to the cowardice gene gives expected results of 0.5 at the start, 0 at 'best for altruism', and 1 at 'worst for altruism', which means that the relative gain on population level from the altruism action at the start is equal to a 1:1 ratio, at 'best for altruism' a 1:0 ratio in favour of altruism, and at 'worst for altruism' a 0:1 ratio in favour of cowardice, so at least this action helps altruism grow if they get above half of the population, but actually helps cowardice grow (and thus altruism relatively shrinks) when altruism has less than half of the population.

The coward behaviour is kind of the opposite: 1-2q (they save themselves, at the cost of their two siblings who have a probability q, to distinguish from p from the altruism formula, that their sibling has the coward gene as well), where q=0.5+0.5×f_c which mirrors p -> at the start q=0.75; when there are only cowards, q=1; when there are only altruism, q=0.5; and the expected gain at each point will therefore be -0.5 at the start, -1 for q=1, and 0 for q=0.5; for the altruists, they have the chance of loss but don't have gain, so their values will be be .25×-2=-0.5 at the start, 0×-2=0 when q=1, and 0.5×-2=-1 when q=0. This gives ratios of 1:1 at the start, -1:0 (disadvantage for cowardice when cowardice is doing well) at q=1, and 0:-1 (disadvantage for altruism when altruism is doing well) at q=0

Furthermore, the chance of these strategies happening is also dependent on the ratio of the genes in the population.

Combining it all we can now have a couple of formulae:
p_a=0.5+0.5×f_a_ (the probability of an altruist's sibling being an altruist)
p_c=0.5×f_c_ (the probability of an altruist's sibling being a coward)
q_c=0.5+0.5×f_c_ (the probability of a coward's sibling being a coward)
q_a=0.5×f_a (the probability of a coward's sibling being an altruist)
G_a=2p_a-1 (the absolute expected gain from an altruistic action for the altruists)
G_c=2p_c (the absolute expected gain from an altruistic action for the cowards)
L_c=2q_c-1 (the absolute expected loss from a cowardice action for the cowards)
L_a=2q_a (the absolute expected loss from a cowardice action for the altruists)
C_a=G_a×f_a - L_a×f_c (the absolute expected change in altruist population)
C_c=G_c×f_a - L_c×f_c (the absolute expected change in coward population)
P_a_n = P_a_(n-1)+C_a (the population of altruists at the nth generation based on the n-1th generation and the expected change)
P_c_n = P_c_(n-1)+C_c (the population of cowardice at the nth generation based on the n-1th generation and the expected change)
these new population numbers can then be used to determine the ratios f_a and f_c that feed into the next generation

Ultimately, altruism helps whoever is dominant, whereas cowardice hinders whoever is dominant, but when altruism is dominant, there will also be more altruist actions and thus a net gain for altruism, whereas if cowardice is dominant, there will also be more cowardice actions and thus a net loss for cowardice; in both cases altruism relatively would seem to get the best deal, but at the start, some simulations could start out favouring cowardice, and others favouring altruism, but generally altruism is more likely to win out in the long run.

One fun think to think about is the emergence of the allele.
Genetic mutations happen at random. Considering an Altruisme allele might appear amongst a population full of Cowardice allele : you start with 1 blob with this allele. Then it must survive the day to get a chance to reproduce. Then it must get lucky enough to pass it's allele to at least one member of its puddle. Then the same applies to it's offsprings.

One simple way to think about that emergence it to go back on the dices exemple : if you start with a single coin, the hamilton rule is the same : +1/6. However, when you roll you dice for the first time, you have 1 way to move on, and 5 ways to lose your only coin ==> 5/6 probability of extinction.

NB : the result of the hamilton's rule happens to be the probability of non-extinction with only one coin. This is a coincidence. It would be different if the net gain of rolling 6 were 7 for exemple. The probablility of non-extinction would still be 1/6, while the hamilton's rule would give us 2/6

18:16 On another note, one way to understand why the group not identical by descent is taken into account might be as follows. It actually IS, while we were trying to count it a second time. Imagine a situation where the 2 parents have the altruism allele, the hamilton rule applies independently for both parents (or both sources of the altruism allele).
If we follow the probabilistic assumption (Bp-C=EV) we can still make sens of the issue : when an altruistic blob A gets offsprings with another altruistic blob B, blob B's impact is taken into account in the probability calculation. But you applied your rule on Every Single Blob. So when blob B gets offsprings with blob A, you take once again into account the impact of both A and B on the probability calculation.

As always great watch. Here are my two thoughts:

I think at least part of the reason why r needs to include only same by descent is that you didn't model the population limit as part of Bp - C > 0. If you think about it the cowardice doesn't have negative EV - and with population being limited it most likely is positive. But the population limits shifts (and scales?) EVs so that EV across population is 0; so what you thought is positive EV for altruistic gene might be actually negative. I have no idea how to model it properly, but maybe using r instead of p can be proven to do exactly this?

The second thought - far less significant - is that during estimation of p/r you kind of skipped the part why B = 2, r = 0.5 works when we have two sibilings. If you think about it, the actuall outcomes are more complicated, there is 50% of saving a single same by descent gene, and 25% of saving two (and 25% of none). So why using B=2 and r=0.5 works? The expected values fully explain it, but the neat trick to see why it works is to separate two sibilings in equation Br + Br - C with B=1 and r=0.5. Now it is clear that 2 * 0.5 - C correctly models this scenario.

A factor that I think matters is that the probability calculation itself might be flawed.

Let's say that we have two unbiased coins, and we flip them. We know that at least one of them is heads, what is the chance that the other one is also heads?

We could label that coin as C1, and the other one as C2. Because C1 and C2 don't influence each other, C2 has a 50% chance of being heads, right?

Well, not really. If one coin was heads and the other tails, we could always pick one as heads, and the other is guaranteed to be tails. If both are heads, which one we pick doesn't matter, and the other is guaranteed to be heads. The case where the other coin is guaranteed to be tails is actually two times as probable as the case where it is guaranteed to be heads. So, the chance of the second one being heads ends up as 0.33.

See also: Monty Hall Problem

Hamilton's rule Br - C > 0 is a stronger condition of the expected value condition Bp - C > 0, because in this case: p = r + f_a where f_a ist the additional term dependant on allele frequency?

I.e. Hamilton's rule being satisfied implies the "altruistic allele" having a (maybe only slightly) better outcome than the other one, whereas in the other case (the expected value condition), the fitness depends on the frequency of the alleles, producing "tipping points" like those shown at 14:21, where randomness can tip the simulation in either direction
